For non-sedated patients we used the worst value in the first 24 hours; for sedated patients we used the pre-sedation GCS.
Mortality Probability Models (MPM) II differ slightly in that they use categorical variables (with the exception of age) for mortality prediction [ 4].

We tried to minimize variability by having a written reference of definitions based on the original articles of the various scoring systems and having one person coordinate the process of data collection.
Many of these patients were under the influence of sedation and the worst GCS would reflect the effect of sedation more than the true underlying mental status.
It has been documented that physicians tend to be more selective in their ICU admissions at times of bed shortages, with patients with higher severity of illness being admitted [ 25].
Some patients had more than one severe chronic illness.
Our database also has more severe chronic illnesses (32%) compared with 5-29% in different participating ICUs in the APACHE II development database.
The main reason for ICU admission, whether the admission was after emergency surgery, and the presence of severe chronic illness were documented in accordance with the original definitions [ 2].
The demographics of the 969 eligible patients are shown in Table 1. It is noteworthy that 32% of all patients had one or more severe chronic illnesses.
Severe hepatic disease was the leading chronic illness, followed by immunosuppression, severe respiratory illness, renal illness and cardiovascular illness.

This approach has been shown to be associated with better performance of APACHE II than the approach that assumes normal GCS for sedated patients [ 10].
Second, as discussed above, collecting the data over a relatively long period by different physicians has implications for consistency of data collection.
In our study, the relatively high level of severity of illness was probably related to a combination of all these factors.
This factor probably contributes to our high severity of illness and could have affected system calibration.
SMRs for all system were not significantly different from 1, indicating accurate overall mortality prediction.
On the basis of linear regression analysis, mortalities predicted by all four systems correlated with each other ( P < 0.001 for all combinations).
In our study, the relatively high level of severity of illness was probably related to a combination of all these factors.
Consequently, many desperately ill patients are admitted to the ICU with very high severity of illness and no meaningful chance of survival.
